Description: The Department of Justice, 21 states, and the District of Columbia reached a nearly $864 million settlement agreement with Moody's Investors Service Inc., Moody's Analytics Inc., and their parent, Moody's Corporation resolving allegations arising from Moody's role in providing flawed credit ratings for Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities (RMBS) and Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDO) that contributed to the financial crisis.

Moody's Investors Service Inc., one of the largest credit ratings agencies in the United States, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $195,000 criminal fine for obstructing justice by destroying documents called for during an antitrust investigation.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Moody's Corporation, a credit rating agency, agreed to pay $426.5 million to settle multistate litigation relating to alleged misconduct in inflating ratings of residential mortgage-backed securities. This was part of a larger $864 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-moodys-corporation

Moody's Investors Service, Inc., Standard & Poor's, and Fitch, Inc. agreed to settlements that totalled approximately $900,000 in credits after the state alleged that they misrepresented the meaning of their public bond ratings and gave lower ratings to public bonds, resulting in increased costs of borrowing for the state, cities, towns and school districts. The announcement did not specify how much each company would provide in credits. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.
